prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I sent a screenshot of my “friend” making fun of my girlfriend who has chemo to his mom?
(M 18) I was in a group chat with a bunch of friends and we were talking about the upcoming lacrosse season. All of a sudden out of nowhere my friend goes, “Why do you sound like such a bitch?”. I thought he was just messing around and I said “Why don’t you hit up the gym and get your weight up?” Because he’s short and skinny. He responded with, “That’s why I’m gonna fuck your 400 pound fatass girlfriend”. 

My jaw hit the floor, my girlfriend has been going through chemo since December and is currently swollen and bloated because her kidneys aren’t working properly. Her lupus was so bad that she was a day away from dying. (Her swelling made her go from 108-170 btw)

I told him that he went way too far and he just said, “Don’t talk shit then”. He’s obviously has no remorse for what he says and I don’t know what to do or say. 

I know it might be a shitty thing to do but I’m not trying to escalate things in front of my other friends, they dont really know what to do and they haven’t taken any side yet. 

We all help this kid hide shit from his parents all the time. I know it might not be the most moral thing to do but he’s making my blood boil and it’s either that or I say something about his real dad leaving him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The author's response was to confront the friend, but when that didn't work, they're thinking of involving the friend's parents. 

Now, the ethical aspect here. Sending a screenshot to the friend's mom could be seen as a form of retaliation. However, the friend's comment was hurtful and targeted someone who's vulnerable. The author is trying to protect their girlfriend and hold the friend accountable. On the other hand, the author's initial response might have been a bit harsh, but the friend didn't apologize and continued with more offensive remarks. 

The author is also considering not escalating further in front of friends, which shows they're trying to manage the situation carefully. The friends are unsure how to react, and the author feels the need to take action because the friend has no remorse. 

Is sending the screenshot to the friend's mom wrong? It depends on perspective. Some might argue it's an overstep because it's involving parents in a personal conflict, but others might see it as necessary to make the friend understand the severity of his words. The friend's comment was not just a joke but a cruel one about a sensitive health issue. The author's actions could be a way to show the parent the inappropriateness of the son's behavior, especially if the parent is unaware of the context. 

Alternatively, the author could be seen as retaliating, but the original insult was directed at their girlfriend during a vulnerable time. The line between self-defense and overreaction is thin here. The key is whether the author's action is morally wrong. Considering the context, the friend's lack of remorse, and the serious nature of the joke, the author's intention to address it by involving parents might be justified.
